questions.text: Which of the following culture media is used to grow Mycobacterium tuberculosis?
questions.explanation:
Investigations

Purpose

Advantages

Limitations

Sputum smear

  • Initial screening for pulmonary TB.
  • Samples are stained using the Ziehl-Neelsen method or Auramine-O stain to visualize acid-fast bacilli (AFB) under a microscope.
  • Quick and inexpensive. Can provide results within a few hours.
  • Low sensitivity, especially in cases of extrapulmonary TB or in patients with HIV.
  • Cannot differentiate between Mycobacterium tuberculosis and non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM).

Culture Methods
  • Confirm the diagnosis of TB and assess drug susceptibility.
  • Solid Media: Sputum is inoculated onto solid culture media like Löwenstein-Jensen or Middlebrook agar.
  • Liquid Media: Automated systems like BACTEC or MGIT are used to detect growth faster.
  • The gold standard for TB diagnosis.
  • Allows for drug susceptibility testing.
  • Time-consuming; results can take weeks.
  • Requires specialized laboratory facilities.

Xpert MTB/RIF
  • Detects Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance.
  • Method:
  • A cartridge-based system that performs nucleic acid amplification (NAAT).
  • Sputum or other specimens are processed directly in the cartridge.
  • Rapid results (within 2 hours).
  • High sensitivity and specificity.
  • Simultaneously detects rifampicin resistance.
  • More expensive than smear microscopy.
  • Does not provide full drug susceptibility testing.

LAMP (Loop-Mediated Isothermal Amplification)
  • Detects DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Method:
  • Amplifies DNA at a constant temperature without the need for thermal cycling.
  • Sputum or other specimens are used.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 hours).
  • High specificity and sensitivity.
  • Can be performed at the point of care.
  • Used for patients with HIV with CD4+ counts of less than 100 cells/μL irrespective of signs and symptoms of TB.
  • Less widely available than PCR-based tests.
  • Cannot detect drug resistance directly.

TrueNat
  • Point-of-care test for TB detection.
  • Method:
  • Uses a micro-PCR technology to amplify DNA.
  • Results are available within 60 minutes.
  • Portable and easy to use in peripheral health facilities.
  • Provides results quickly, facilitating immediate treatment decisions.
  

Line Probe Assay (LPA)
  • Detects TB and drug resistance (rifampicin and isoniazid).
  • Method:
    • Sputum samples are processed, and DNA is extracted.
    • Amplified DNA is hybridized to specific probes on a membrane strip.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 days).
  • Can detect multiple mutations associated with drug resistance.
  • Requires a laboratory setup and trained personnel.
  • Not suitable for all strains of TB.

RFLP
  • IS6110 restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis is widely used for molecular epidemiological studies of tuberculosis.
  • Restriction enzymes Nru I, EcoN I, Pst I, and Pvu II were used to analyze IS6110 fingerprints in Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains H37Rv (virulent) and H37Ra (avirulent).

References:

Type of E. coli

Clinical Features

Toxins Produced

Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC)

Watery diarrhea, Abdominal cramps, Low-grade fever, Nausea and vomiting

Most common cause of traveller's diarrhea

Causes watery diarrhea through

attachment via CFA (colonization factor antigen) and toxin production (heat-labile toxin ↑cAMP, heat-stable toxin ↑cGMP).

Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC)

Watery diarrhea (especially in infants), Fever, Vomiting, Dehydration

None (mechanism involves attaching and effacing lesions)

Shiga-like toxins/Verocytotoxin

Watery diarrhea (usually mild), Abdominal cramps, Low-grade fever

None (mechanism involves diffuse adherence to epithelial cells)

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman was hospitalized for three days for left leg cellulitis. She was treated with clindamycin. Two days after her discharge, abdominal pain, and watery diarrhea. Lab results showed leukocytes 17,500/mm3, elevated ESR and CRP. What is the causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Diagnosis

1. Colonoscopy
  • Examination of the colon whitish-yellow plaques on the colonic mucosa known as microabscesses.
  • Although it is highly specific, it is not as sensitive as ELISA, hence it is not considered the Gold standard for diagnosis.

2. Culture
  • Stool samples cultured on selective media to identify C. difficile; less sensitive than toxin detection.

3. Toxin Detection
  • ELISA: Detects toxins A and/or B in stool samples, the gold standard.
  • Cell Culture: Toxins produce characteristic effects on Hep-2 or human diploid cell cultures, neutralized by C. sordellii antitoxin.

4. Molecular Methods
  • PCR: Detects genes coding for toxins A and B in stool samples.

5. Histopathology
  • This can be performed with hematoxylin and eosin stains
  • Highly specific but low sensitivity

Treatment

Antibiotic Discontinuation
  • Stop the antibiotic suspected of contributing to the infection.

Antibiotic Therapy
  • Oral vancomycin or metronidazole.
  • Severe cases: Combination of oral vancomycin, intravenous metronidazole, and rectal vancomycin enemas.

Prevention

Antibiotic Stewardship
  • Limit the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics like clindamycin, ampicillin, and fluoroquinolones; prevent disruption of normal gut flora.

Infection Control Measures
  • Meticulous hand hygiene and contact precautions in healthcare settings.

Recent Treatment Option

Fecal Transplants
  • Replenishing gut flora with donated faeces from screened healthy donor

questions.text: A farmer presents with a lesion on his arm after working with cattle on his farm. Gram staining of a sample from the lesion reveals gram-positive rods with square ends and central spores. What is the most likely organism causing this lesion?
questions.explanation:
Name

Microscopy

Features

Bacillus Anthracis

Bacillus anthracis appears as large (3-10 µm x 1-1.6 µm), rectangular, rod-shaped bacteria (“box-car appearance”), often arranged in chains. It is Gram-positive.

It is

 

Characteristic

Description

Blood Agar
  • Large (2 to 5 mm), grey, flat, non-hemolytic colonies with irregular margins- giving a frosted glass appearance.
  • Tenacious consistency firmly adheres to agar.
  • "Medusa head" appearance under microscope.

Agar with Penicillin
  • Susceptible to penicillin.
  • Grows large, spherical cells in 3-6 hours on media with 0.05-0.50 units of penicillin/ml.
  • Forms "string of pearls" chains.

Gelatin Liquefaction
  • Obligate aerobe.
  • More growth and energy production at the surface.
  • Liquefaction starts from the top, resembling an "inverted fir tree".

PLET Medium

 

 
  • Contains polymyxin, lysozyme, EDTA, and thallous acetate in heart infusion agar (PLET)
  • Selective for isolating B. anthracis from samples with other spore-forming bacilli.

Serology

 

 

 
  • Ascoli's Thermoprecipitin Test: Detects anthrax antigens in tissue extracts.
  • DFA: Detects antibodies against B. anthracis; confirms presence via cell wall polysaccharide and capsule antigens.

Laboratory Safety Note
  • High risk of infection from spores.
  • Caution is advised when handling B.anthracis isolates.

questions.text: A patient with meningitis was examined. His CSF shows lymphocytosis, decreased glucose, and increased protein. What is the etiological agent?
questions.explanation:
TB Meningitis

Pathophysiology
  • Tuberculous Meningitis results from hematogenous spread of primary or postprimary TB or rupture of a subependymal tubercle into the subarachnoid space.

Onset

Evolves over 1–2 weeks, slower than bacterial meningitis.

Symptoms
  • Early Symptoms
    • Headache, mild mental changes, low-grade fever, malaise, anorexia, irritability over several weeks.
  • Advanced Symptoms
    • Severe headache, confusion, lethargy, altered sensorium, neck rigidity, cranial nerve palsies (especially ocular). Can progress to coma, hydrocephalus, and intracranial hypertension.

Lumbar Puncture Findings (CSF)
  • High leukocyte count (up to 1000/μL), typically lymphocyte predominance
  • Protein: 1–8 g/L (100–800 mg/dL)
  • Low glucose concentration
  • AFB is rarely seen; repeated lumbar punctures increase yield.
  • CSF culture diagnostic in up to 80% (gold standard).

Xpert MTB/RIF Assay
  • Sensitivity up to 80%.
  • A negative result does not exclude TB.

Imaging
  • CT, MRI: Shows hydrocephalus and enhancement of basal cisterns or ependyma.

Basal cistern enhancement

  • In >50% of cases, old pulmonary lesions or military pattern on CXR.

Treatment

Immediate treatment with positive Xpert MTB/RIF.

  • Chemotherapy is effective but neurologic sequelae occur in 25% of cases, especially with delayed diagnosis.
  • Glucocorticoid Therapy
    • Dexamethasone reduces mortality and severe disability but may not prevent neurological sequelae.
    • Regimen: 0.4 mg/kg/day IV, tapering weekly, followed by oral tapering. WHO recommends tapering over 6–8 weeks.

questions.text: A patient has a fever, rash, and eschar formation due to a mite bite. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Scrub typhus

Causative agent

Orientia tsutsugamushi - It differs from Rickettsia both genetically and by its cell wall composition i.e. it lacks lipopolysaccharide layer.

Vector

Chiggers (larvae of trombiculid mite)

Pathophysiology
  • Scrub typhus is so named because it occurs in scrub vegetation i.e. low-lying trees and bushes.
  • The bite of infected trombiculid mites transmits it.
  • Among all stages of mite, the larvae (called chiggers) are the only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Mites can maintain the organisms through transovarial transmission.
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi infects mononuclear cells but still produces fever and rash.

Clinical features

  • The classic presentation of scrub typhus consists of triad of an eschar (at the site of bite), regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash sparing palms and soles.
  • Non-specific manifestations may appear early such as fever, headache, myalgia, cough, and gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • Complications such as encephalitis and interstitial pneumonia may occur rarely in the late stage (due to vascular injury).

Investigations

  • The Weil-Felix test shows OX K+ only.

Treatment

  • Doxycycline is the drug choice.
  • Azithromycin is given alternatively and the drug of choice in children and pregnant women.

questions.explanation:
Morphology

Biochemical Properties

Growth & Susceptibility

Small, non-motile, aerobic, Gram-negative coccobacilli

Catalase positive

Do not grow well on standard laboratory media

Non-capsulated and non-spore forming

Oxidase positive (except B. neotomae and B. ovis)

Destroyed by heat at 60°C in 10 minutes

Often exhibit a bipolar staining appearance

Urease positive

Killed by 1% phenol in 15 minutes
 

Utilize oxygen but do not typically ferment carbohydrates

Killed by pasteurization

Test

Description

Key Points

Standard Agglutination Test (SAT)

Tube agglutination test using serial dilutions of patient's serum and killed B. abortus antigen
  • Significant titer: 160 or more.
  • Acute brucellosis titer: 640 or more within 3-4 weeks.
  • Prozone phenomenon common.
  • False positives with cholera, tularemia, yersinia infection, or immunization

Complement Fixation Test

Detects IgG antibodies
  • Valuable in chronic cases

ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay)

Distinguishes between IgM and IgG antibodies
  • Useful for differentiating acute from chronic infections

Rapid Tests

Includes rapid dipstick tests and Rose Bengal card test
  • Quick results.
  • Can be used for initial screening

Characteristic

Details

Morphology

Small, non-motile, aerobic, Gram-negative coccobacilli, Non-capsulated, non-spore forming, Bipolar staining

Biochemical Properties

Catalase positive, Oxidase positive (except B. neotomae and B. ovis), Urease positive, Utilize oxygen, do not ferment carbohydrates

Growth & Susceptibility

Do not grow well on standard media. Destroyed by heat at 60°C in 10 min, Killed by 1% phenol in 15 min, Killed by pasteurization.

Zoonotic Nature

Affects goats, sheep, cattle, buffaloes, pigs. Human infection through contact or consumption.

Symptoms

Intermittent fever, loss of appetite, nausea, muscular and articular pains, fatigue, sweating, relative bradycardia, joint pain.

Blood Culture

Trypticase soy broth or brucella broth. Biphasic blood culture (Castaneda method). Large blood volume (5 ml). Incubation: 37°C, 5-10% CO2, 6-8 weeks. 30-50% positive cases. Bone marrow cultureshave a higher yield.

Serological Tests

SAT: Significant titer 160+, Acute 640+, Complement Fixation: IgG detection, ELISA: Distinguishes IgM & IgG. Rapid Tests: Dipstick, Rose Bengal

Antibiotics

Adults: Doxycycline 45 days, Streptomycin 2 weeks, Children: Cotrimoxazole + Rifampicin/Gentamycin.

Vaccination

No human vaccine, Occupational risk: Attenuated live vaccine, Animals: B. abortus strain 19 vaccine.

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of watery diarrhea and vomiting. The pathogen exhibited darting motility. Which is the best selective media for the involved pathogen?
Which of the following is the mechanism of action of diphtheria toxin?

options.label: A
options.text: ADP phosphorylation of EF-2 - Decreasing protein synthesis

questions.correct_answer: A. ADP phosphorylation of EF-2 - Decreasing protein synthesis
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Production and Structure
  • DT is a protein exotoxin produced by the toxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
  • Consists of two fragments(Bipartite), A and B, with a molecular weight of approximately 62,000 daltons.

Role of Lysogenic β-phage
  • The tox gene is carried by a lysogenic β-phage.
  • Only phage-infected strains produce toxin; nontoxigenic strains can become toxigenic if infected.
  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae remains localized at the infection site, with only the toxin entering circulation, causing toxaemia but not bacteremia.

Mechanism of Action
  • Fragment B binds host cell receptors, facilitating fragment A entry into the cytoplasm.
  • Fragment A catalyses ADP-ribosylation of EF-2, halting protein synthesis.

Potency
  • The lethal dose for a 250g guinea pig: is 0.0001 mg.
  • The estimated lethal dose for humans: 130 ng/kg body weight.

Systemic Effects
  • DT spreads via blood, causing myocarditis and neuritis.
  • Myocarditis is potentially fatal.

Factors Affecting Production
  • Influenced by environmental factors: alkaline pH (7.8-8.0), oxygen, and iron concentration in the growth medium.
  • High production with low iron availability (0.1 mg/l); iron addition inhibits production (0.5 mg/l).

Toxoid Formation
  • Treatment with formalin (0.2-0.4%), and incubation at 37°C for 4-6 weeks converts DT to toxoid.
  • Toxoid lacks toxicity but induces an immune response; used in vaccines.

Immunity
  • Immunity is primarily mediated by antitoxin antibodies neutralizing DT.

Toxin

Source

Mechanism of Action

Diphtheria Toxin (DT)

Corynebacterium diphtheriae
  • Secreted by bacteria infected with tox-carrying β-phage.
  • Cleaved into fragments B and A.
  • Fragment B binds to human cell receptors.
  • Fragment A ADP-ribosylates elongation factor 2 (EF-2), halting protein synthesis.

Exotoxin A

Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • Secreted by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  • Inhibits protein synthesis in eukaryotic cells.
  • The mechanism involves a similar process to DT, disrupting EF-2 function.

Exotoxins

Streptokinase

 

Enzyme

  • Deep tissue infections,
  • pharyngitis

DNases (A, B, C, D)

Enzymes

Depolymerize free DNA in pus, reducing viscosity and aiding the spread
  • Abscess formation,
  • skin infections

C5a Peptidase

Enzyme

Degrades the C5a component of the complement system, inhibiting chemotaxis of phagocytes
  • Immune evasion,
  • systemic infections

Capsule

Polysaccharide capsule

Composed of hyaluronic acid; inhibits phagocytosis
  • Severe invasive diseases,
  • immune evasion

questions.explanation:
Bacterial Meningitis in Adults and Prevention

Causes

Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitides are the primary causes. Listeria monocytogenes is a significant risk in adults over 50, especially in those with diabetes, alcoholism, or weakened immune systems.

Pathophysiological Process

Treatment
  • Immediate Management: Start with intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover pathogens. Treatment is then changed based on the identified organism and its susceptibility.
  • Adjunctive Therapy: Dexamethasone may be given to reduce inflammation and prevent complications, particularly if administered early.
  • Supportive Care: Manage complications like raised intracranial pressure and seizures.

Prevention

 
  • Vaccines for H. influenzae type b, N. meningitidis, and S. pneumoniae. No vaccine currently exists for group B meningococcal infections.
  • Chemoprophylaxis: Close contacts of individuals with meningococcal meningitis should receive prophylactic antibiotics like rifampicin, ciprofloxacin, azithromycin or ceftriaxone to reduce the risk of secondary infections.
    • Rifampicin - 600 mg 12 hourly for 2 days
    • Ciprofloxacin - 500 mg single dose
    • Azithromycin 500 mg single dose
    • Ceftriaxone - 250 mg Intramuscular single dose

questions.text: A farmer presents with fever and physical examination findings as seen in the image. His serum creatinine is 1.4 mg/dL, and platelet count is 88,000/mm³. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Scrub typhus

Causative agent

Orientia tsutsugamushi - It differs from Rickettsia both genetically and by its cell wall composition i.e. it lacks lipopolysaccharide layer.

Vector

Chiggers (larvae of trombiculid mite)

Pathophysiology
  • Scrub typhus is so named because it occurs in areas of scrub vegetation i.e. low lying trees and bushes.
  • It is transmitted by the bite of infected trombiculid mites.
  • Among all stages of mite, the larvae (called chiggers) are the only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Mites can maintain the organisms through transovarial transmission.
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi infects mononuclear cells but still produces fever and rash.

Clinical features

  • The classic presentation of scrub typhus consists of triad of an eschar (at the site of bite), regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash sparing palms and soles.
  • Non-specific manifestations may appear early such as fever, headache, myalgia, cough, and gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • Complications such as encephalitis and interstitial pneumonia may occur rarely in the late stage (due to vascular injury).

Investigations

The Weil-Felix test shows OX K+ only.

Treatment

  • Doxycycline is the drug choice.
  • Azithromycin is given alternatively and the drug of choice in children and pregnant women.

questions.text: Which bacterial toxin acts by interfering with the function of elongation factor-2 (EF-2)?
questions.explanation:
Diphtheria Toxin

Production and Structure
  • DT is a protein exotoxin produced by the toxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
  • Consists of two fragments (Bipartite), A and B, with a molecular weight of approximately 62,000 daltons.

Role of Lysogenic β-phage
  • The tox gene is carried by a lysogenic β-phage.
  • Only phage-infected strains produce toxin; nontoxigenic strains can become toxigenic if infected.
  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae remains localized at the infection site, with only the toxin entering circulation, causing toxaemia but not bacteremia.

Mechanism of Action
  • Fragment B binds host cell receptors, facilitating fragment A entry into the cytoplasm.
  • Fragment A catalyses ADP-ribosylation of EF-2, halting protein synthesis.

Systemic Effects
  • DT spreads via blood, causing myocarditis and neuritis.
  • Myocarditis is potentially fatal.

Factors Affecting Production
  • Influenced by environmental factors: alkaline pH (7.8-8.0), oxygen, and iron concentration in the growth medium.
  • High production with low iron availability; iron addition inhibits production.

Toxoid Formation
  • Treatment with formalin (0.2-0.4%), and incubation at 37°C for 4-6 weeks converts DT to toxoid.
  • Toxoid lacks toxicity but induces an immune response; used in vaccines.

Immunity
  • Immunity is primarily mediated by antitoxin antibodies neutralizing DT.

questions.explanation:
Leptospirosis

Agent
  • Leptospira interrogans (zoonotic bacteria)

Reservoir
  • Rodents (Ratus norvegicus, Mus musculus) and domestic animals

Source
  • Direct contact or contamination with excreta, urine of infected animals.

At risk individuals
  • Males 20-45 years (most common)
  • Urine-contaminated mud(Soil) or water
    • Sports: Rafting, fishing and swimming
    • Rice field workers, sewer workers, animal handlers

Mode of transmission
  • Direct contact: Urine through skin abrasion
  • Indirect contact: Contact of broken skin with soil, water, vegetation
  • Droplet infection: Inhalation while milking cows.

Incubation
  • 4-20 days

Diagnosis
  • Clinical features
  • Dark Field examination: Thin and motile spirochete.
  • IgM ELISA: High sensitivity
  • Labs: Elevated liver enzymes, increased bilirubin, thrombocytopenia

questions.text: A man presents with dysuria and urethral discharge after having unprotected sexual intercourse. Gram staining of the purulent discharge is shown in the image. What is the treatment of choice for this infection?
questions.explanation:
Urethritis

Etiology

Infectious Causes:

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae (gonococcal)
  • Chlamydia trachomatis (nongonococcal)
  • Mycoplasma genitalium (recurrent urethritis)
  • Trichomonas vaginalis (protozoal)
  • Other: HSV, Treponema pallidum, Candida, Corynebacterium, Haemophilus influenzae

Non-Infectious Causes:

  • Irritants (soaps, spermicides, tight clothing)
  • Trauma (catheterization, instrumentation)
  • Menopause (low estrogen, atrophic vaginitis)

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms:
    • Dysuria (worse in morning, alcohol-exacerbated)
    • Urethral discharge (varies by pathogen)
    • Urethral pruritus, orchalgia (testicular pain in men)
    • Systemic symptoms rare (except viral causes)
  • Discharge Characteristics:
    • Thick, yellow-green → N. gonorrhoeae
    • Clear, white → C. trachomatis
    • Purulent/mucopurulent → M. genitalium

Diagnosis

Clinical suspicion in sexually active individuals with urethral symptoms.

Laboratory Tests:

  • Gram stain: Gram-negative intracellular diplococci (gonococcal)
  • NAAT (preferred): Detects C. trachomatis, N. gonorrhoeae, T. vaginalis, M. genitalium
  • Additional: Cultures, fungal KOH prep, NAAT for syphilis/HIV, pregnancy testing, wet mount for T. vaginalis (low sensitivity).

Alternative Methods:

  • MB/GV smear (similar to gram stain, sensitivity 97.3%)
  • Urethral culture (for N. gonorrhoeae resistance testing)
  • C. trachomatis suspected if pyuria present but no bacteria on stain/culture
  • M. genitalium confirmed only via NAAT (limited availability)

Emerging Pathogens

Haemophilus spp. increasingly linked to nongonococcal urethritis, especially with oral exposure.

Treatment

Indications for Antibiotics:

  • Positive gram stain/culture
  • Contact with an infected partner
  • Clinical urethritis without confirmed etiology if follow-up is uncertain.

Gonococcal Urethritis:

  • Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM (if <150 kg) or 1 g IM (if ≥150 kg)
  • If C. Trachomatis not ruled out: Add Doxycycline 100 mg PO BID x 7 days
  • Alternatives: Gentamicin + Azithromycin or Cefixime

Nongonococcal Urethritis:

  • Doxycycline 100 mg PO BID x 7 days (preferred)
  • Alternative: Azithromycin (multi-day better than single dose)

Persistent/Recurrent Urethritis:

  • M. genitalium suspected: Doxycycline 7 days → Moxifloxacin 400 mg PO daily x 7 days
  • If T. vaginalis suspected: NAAT confirmation or empiric Metronidazole 2 g PO

Special Cases

Pregnancy:

  • Azithromycin 1 g PO (preferred)
  • Alternatives: Amoxicillin, Erythromycin (varied dosing)
  • Avoid: Doxycycline, Quinolones

Resistant M. Genitalium: Moxifloxacin or Pristinamycin

T. vaginalis Treatment:

  • Women: Metronidazole 500 mg PO BID x 7 days
  • Men: Metronidazole 2 g PO single dose
  • Sexual partners must be treated to prevent reinfection.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents with fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea for 3 days. He reports consuming raw fish prior to symptom onset. He is hemodynamically stable, and stool examination reveals no pus cells. Culture grows on Wagatsuma agar. What is the most likely causative agent?
A 45-year-old man with multiple sexual partners presents with a palmoplantar rash. On examination, he has mucocutaneous papules on the scrotum and lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A cattle farmer presented with a lesion on the arm as shown below. Gram staining showed gram-positive rods as shown below. Identify the organism.
questions.explanation:
Name

Microscopy

Features

a. Bacillus Anthracis

Bacillus anthracis appears as large (3-10 µm x 1-1.6 µm), rectangular, rod-shaped bacteria (“box-car appearance”), often arranged in chains. It is Gram-positive.

It is

 

Characteristic

Description

Blood Agar
  • Large (2 to 5 mm), grey, flat, non-hemolytic colonies with irregular margins- giving a frosted glass appearance.
  • Tenacious consistency firmly adheres to agar.
  • "Medusa head" appearance under microscope.

Agar with Penicillin
  • Susceptible to penicillin.
  • Grows large, spherical cells in 3-6 hours on media with 0.05-0.50 units of penicillin/ml.
  • Forms "string of pearls" chains.

Gelatin Liquefaction

 

 

 

 
  • Obligate aerobe.
  • More growth and energy production at the surface.
  • Liquefaction starts from the top, resembling an "inverted fir tree".

PLET Medium

 

 
  • Contains polymyxin, lysozyme, EDTA, and thallous acetate in heart infusion agar (PLET)
  • Selective for isolating B. anthracis from samples with other spore-forming bacilli.

Serology

 

 

 
  • Ascoli's Thermoprecipitin Test: Detects anthrax antigens in tissue extracts.
  • DFA: Detects antibodies against B. anthracis; confirms presence via cell wall polysaccharide and capsule antigens.

Laboratory Safety Note
  • High risk of infection from spores.
  • Caution is advised when handling B.anthracis isolates.

questions.text: Which of the following is an acid-fast organism?
A young man presents with skin lesions as shown in the image below. identify the cause
questions.explanation:
Disease caused by staphylococcus

Key features

Primary infection

Furuncle

Superficial skin infection develops in hair follicles, sebaceous gland, or sweat gland.

Carbuncle

Development of one or more abscesses in adjacent subcutaneous tissues due to the spread of infection from a furuncle.

Impetigo

The exfoliative toxin produced causes bullous impetigo, characterized by blisters.

Non-bullous impetigo is caused by streptococcus.

Acute osteomyelitis

Bacterial growth usually concentrates in a terminal blood artery of the metaphysis of a long bone, resulting in bone necrosis and persistent suppuration.

Necrotizing pneumonia
  • Caused by strains producing the PVL leukocidin.
  • Localized, destructive abscesses

Endocarditis
  • In drug addicts
  • Due to bacteremia

Toxins mediated

Scalded skin syndrome

Erythema and intraepidermal desquamation in neonates caused by exfoliative toxin

Toxic shock syndrome
  • TSST-1 (Toxic Shock Syndrome Toxin)
  • Early findings: Fever, vomiting, diarrhea, muscle pain
  • Later: Shock, renal, and hepatic injury, MODS
  • Tampon-associated

Staphylococcal food poisoning
  • Vomiting is prominent without fever.
  • Ingestion of enterotoxin-contaminated food causing acute vomiting and diarrhea within 1 to 5 hours of ingestion

questions.text: Mode of transmission of abdominal TB includes all except

options.label: A
options.text: Direct spread from mesenteric lymph nodes

questions.explanation:
Gastrointestinal Tuberculosis

Mechanisms of Infection
  • Swallowing of sputum with direct seeding.
  • Hematogenous spread.
  • Ingestion of contaminated bovine milk (common in developing areas).

Common sites of infection
  • Terminal ileum and cecum.

Symptoms
  • Abdominal: Pain (similar to appendicitis), swelling, obstruction, hematochezia, palpable abdominal mass.
  • Systemic: Fever, weight loss, anorexia, night sweats.
  • Complications: Ulcerations and fistulae (mimicking Crohn’s disease); anal fistula suggests rectal TB.

Diagnosis

  • Surgery is required to obtain histologic and culture specimens intraoperatively.
  • Differential Diagnosis: Difficult to distinguish from Crohn’s disease.

Tuberculous Peritonitis

Pathophysiology
  • Results from the direct spread of tubercle bacilli from ruptured lymph nodes or intra-abdominal organs (e.g., genital TB in women), or hematogenous spread.

Symptoms
  • Abdominal: Nonspecific abdominal pain, ascites.
  • Systemic: Fever.
  • Complication: Coexistence with cirrhosis complicates diagnosis.

Diagnosis
  • Paracentesis: Reveals exudative fluid with high protein content and lymphocytic leukocytosis (neutrophils may predominate at times).
  • Direct Smear/Culture: Low yield; culturing large volumes of ascitic fluid may improve results.
  • Peritoneal Biopsy: Typically needed for diagnosis, best obtained via laparoscopy.

Treatment
  • Surgical intervention may be required for diagnosis and management in many cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fever, headache, photophobia, and neck rigidity for the last 2 days. He had undergone a heart transplant one year back and is on immunomodulatory drugs. On microscopy, differential motility was seen, non-motile at 37°C, and motile at 25°C. What is the most likely organism causing this?
questions.explanation:
Listeria monocytogenes

Mode of Transmission
  • Contaminated food
  • Vertical transmission (mother to fetus, during birth)

Common Food Sources
  • Contaminated coleslaw
  • Milk, Soft cheeses
  • "Ready-to-eat" foods (delicatessen meat, uncooked hotdogs)

Age Groups at Risk
  • Neonates
  • Elderly individuals

Increased Risk Factors
  • Use of proton pump inhibitors
  • Pregnant women
  • Immunocompromised individuals

Survival in Food
  • Survives refrigeration (4°C)
  • Found in stored foods (aged soft cheeses, packaged meats, milk, cold salads)

Infection Type
  • Sporadic
  • Outbreaks can occur

Psychrotrophic
  • L. monocytogenes is a psychrotrophic organism with an optimum growth temperature of 30ºC to 37ºC but has the ability to grow at a wide range of temperatures from 1ºC to 45ºC.

Motility
  • Shows Tumbling and Differential motility(motile at 25.C by forming actin rockets, non motile at 37.C)

Pathogenesis
  • Intracellular survival: lysis of phagosome (listeriolysin O)
  • Host cell actin polymerization (cell membrane approach)
  • Direct cell-to-cell spread (listeriopods)

Clinical Manifestations
  • Neonatal listeriosis: Early-onset and late-onset disease
  • Pregnant women:
    • Granulomatosis infantiseptica in baby in 3rd trimester
    • Fetal complications (abortion, preterm delivery)
    • Maternal complications (flu-like symptoms, bacteremia, rarely meningitis)
  • Adults:
    • Bacteremia and meningitis (elderly, >60 years)
    • Immunosuppression- higher risk (steroid therapy, HIV, diabetes, malignancy)
    • Post-kidney transplant meningitis (1-month post-transplant)
    • Gastroenteritis (consumption of contaminated milk, meat, salads)

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of fever for 3 days and general fatigue. Echocardiography revealed vegetations on the valves, and a blood culture was performed. The organism in the culture showed alpha hemolysis on blood agar and was resistant to optochin and bile. Which of the following bacteria is most commonly implicated in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Epidemiology:
  • Dental procedures can introduce Streptococcus viridans into the bloodstream, potentially leading to infective endocarditis.
  • Patients with pre-existing heart conditions, such as valvular heart disease or prosthetic valves, are at higher risk.

Infection Mechanism:
  • Capable of producing biofilms, aiding in adherence to heart valves, and resistance to phagocytosis and antibiotics.
  • Production of extracellular polysaccharides enhances its ability to colonize and persist in host tissues.

Clinical Presentation:
  • Symptoms can include fever, chills, heart murmur, fatigue, and signs of embolic events such as petechiae or splinter hemorrhages.
  • Complications may involve heart failure, systemic embolization, and severe valve dysfunction.

Diagnosis:
  • Blood cultures are essential for identifying the causative organism.
  • Echocardiography (especially transesophageal echocardiography) is used to visualize vegetations on the heart valves

Treatment:
  • Prolonged antibiotic therapy, often involves penicillin or ceftriaxone combined with an aminoglycoside.
  • In some cases, surgical intervention may be necessary to repair or replace damaged valves.

Complications

Function

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with TB and while testing for resistance, he was found to be resistant to Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Amikacin, and Levofloxacin. What is this type of TB called?
questions.explanation:
Category

Description

Drug sensitive TB

Patients are sensitive to 4 TB drugs: R,H,Z,E (Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol).

Mono-resistant (MR) (Option A)

Resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.

H-Mono-resistant (H-MR)

Resistant to Isoniazid (H) only.

Rifampicin resistant (RR) (Option D)

Resistant to Rifampicin (R) only.

Multi drug resistant (MDR) (Option B)

Resistant to both Rifampicin (R) & Isoniazid (H).

Poly-Drug resistant (PDR) (Option A)

Resistant to 2 drugs other than Rifampicin (R) & Isoniazid (H).

Pre-Xtensive resistant (pre-XDR)

Any MDR patient (H+R) resistant to any fluoroquinolone.

Extensive resistant (XDR) (Option C)

Any MDR patient (H+R) resistant to any fluoroquinolone and Group 4 drugs (Bedaquiline, Linezolid, Levo/Moxifloxacin).

questions.text: A farmer with a history of flea bite in a godown presents with high fever, painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, vomiting, diarrhea, and hypotension. Smears prepared from the discharge of these swellings revealed bacteria with bipolar staining. Which stain will help in the diagnosis?

Plague (Yersinia pestis)

Endemic Foci
  • Kolar (Tamil Nadu),
  • Beed Latur (Maharashtra)
  • Rhoru (Himachal)

Reservoir

Wild rodents

Vector

Rat flea (Xenopsylla cheopis, Xenopsylla astia)

Types of Plague
  • Bubonic Plague: 2-7 days incubation period; Lymph node painful enlargement and fever
  • Pneumonic Plague: 1-3 days incubation period; Respiratory symptoms; Associated with bio-terrorism
  • Septicemic Plague: 2-7 days incubation period; A/k/a Black death; DIC, shock and multi-organ failure

Microscopic Findings

Safety pin appearance (Bipolar staining) using Wayson stain, Wright stain, Giemsa stain

Culture
  • Nutrient broth with oil/ghee (Ghee broth): Stalactite growth (hanging from the top)
  • Selective CIN agar: Bullseye colonies

 

Biochemical Reactions

  • Catalase positive
  • Oxidase negative
  • IMViC = - - + -

Vaccine

  • Sokhey's Modification of Haffkine Vaccine- Protects only against bubonic plague,

Treatment

  • Streptomycin
  • Fluoroquinolones: For CNS and cardiovascular involvement

questions.text: What is the probable causative agent involved in the case of two individuals from a group of 20 friends who experienced nausea and vomiting in the early morning after consuming pastries from an external source during a late-night party?
questions.explanation:
Disease caused by Staphylococcus aureus

Key features

Primary infection

Furuncle

Superficial skin infection develops in hair follicles, sebaceous gland, or sweat gland.

Carbuncle

Development of one or more abscesses in adjacent subcutaneous tissues due to the spread of infection from a furuncle.

Impetigo

The exfoliative toxin produced causes bullous impetigo, characterized by blisters.

Non-bullous impetigo is caused by streptococcus.

Acute osteomyelitis

Bacterial growth usually concentrates in a terminal blood artery of the metaphysis of a long bone, resulting in bone necrosis and persistent suppuration.

Necrotizing pneumonia
  • Caused by strains producing the PVL leukocidin.
  • Localized, destructive abscesses

Endocarditis
  • In drug addicts
  • Due to bacteremia

Toxins mediated

Scalded skin syndrome

Erythema and intraepidermal desquamation in neonates caused by exfoliative toxin

Toxic shock syndrome
  • TSST-1 (Toxic Shock Syndrome Toxin)
  • Early findings: Fever, vomiting, diarrhea, muscle pain
  • Later: Shock, renal, and hepatic injury, MODS
  • Tampon-associated

Staphylococcal food poisoning
  • Vomiting is prominent without fever.
  • Ingestion of enterotoxin-contaminated food causing acute vomiting and diarrhea within 1 to 5 hours of ingestion (Option A)

Virulence factors

Key features

Cell wall-associated polymers

 

Peptidoglycan

 

Activates complement-induced release of inflammatory cytokines

Teichoic acid

Adherence to the host cell surface, and shields them from complement-mediated opsonization

Capsular polysaccharide

Inhibits opsonization

Cell surface

Protein A
  • Anti-complementary
  • Anti-phagocytic
  • Co-agglutination

Clumping factor

Responsible for the slide coagulase test

Toxins

Hemolysin

Alpha hemolysin-

  • Lyse sheep and human red blood cells.
  • Toxic to macrophages, lysosomes, muscle tissues, the renal cortex, and the circulatory system

Beta-hemolysins or sphingomyelinase

  • Lyse sheep red blood cells only

Panton-Valentine (PVL) Leucocidin
  • Synergohymenotropic toxin
  • Attacks neutrophils, platelets
  • Produced by Methicillin-Resistant Staph. aureus (MRSA)

Enterotoxin (superantigen)
  • Food poisoning
  • Most cases are caused by type A.
  • It acts directly on the autonomic nervous system causing symptoms. Vomiting is stimulated in the brain stem.

Toxic shock syndrome toxin(TSST) (superantigen)
  • Fatal multisystem disease
  • Tampon-related TSS

Epidermolytic/Exfoliative toxin
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS): the outer layer of the epidermis gets separated from the underlying tissues.
  • Severe form of SSSS: Ritter's disease in the newborn and toxic epidermal necrolysis in older patients.
  • Milder forms: pemphigus neonatorum and bullous impetigo

Enzymes

Coagulase

Clotting of human or rabbit plasma

Lipid hydrolases

Helps in skin and subcutaneous tissue infections

Hyaluronidase
  • Breaks down the connective tissues
  • Staphylokinase, protease

Nuclease

Heat-stable DNase

questions.text: A patient was suspected of having acute brucellosis. A serum sample was sent for a standard agglutination test. It came out to be negative initially, but after serial dilutions of the serum sample, the test turned out to be positive. Which of the following is responsible for the initial negative test?
questions.explanation:
Morphology

Biochemical Properties

Growth & Susceptibility

Small, non-motile, aerobic, Gram-negative coccobacilli

Catalase positive

Do not grow well on standard laboratory media

Non-capsulated and non-spore forming

Oxidase positive (except B. neotomae and B. ovis)

Destroyed by heat at 60°C in 10 minutes

Often exhibit a bipolar staining appearance

Urease positive

Killed by 1% phenol in 15 minutes
 

Utilize oxygen but do not typically ferment carbohydrates

Killed by pasteurization

Test

Description

Key Points

Standard Agglutination Test (SAT)

Tube agglutination test using serial dilutions of patient's serum and killed B. abortus antigen
  • Significant titer: 160 or more.
  • Acute brucellosis titer: 640 or more within 3-4 weeks.
  • Prozone phenomenon common.
  • False positives with cholera, tularemia, yersinia infection, or immunization

Complement Fixation Test

Detects IgG antibodies
  • Valuable in chronic cases

ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay)

Distinguishes between IgM and IgG antibodies
  • Useful for differentiating acute from chronic infections

Rapid Tests

Includes rapid dipstick tests and Rose Bengal card test
  • Quick results.
  • Can be used for initial screening

Characteristic

Details

Morphology

Small, non-motile, aerobic, Gram-negative coccobacilli, Non-capsulated, non-spore forming, Bipolar staining

Biochemical Properties

Catalase positive, Oxidase positive (except B. neotomae and B. ovis), Urease positive, Utilize oxygen, do not ferment carbohydrates

Growth & Susceptibility

Do not grow well on standard media. Destroyed by heat at 60°C in 10 min, Killed by 1% phenol in 15 min, Killed by pasteurization.

Zoonotic Nature

Affects goats, sheep, cattle, buffaloes, pigs. Human infection through contact or consumption.

Symptoms

Intermittent fever, loss of appetite, nausea, muscular and articular pains, fatigue, sweating, joint pain.

Blood Culture

Trypticase soy broth or brucella broth. Biphasic blood culture (Castaneda method). Large blood volume (5 ml). Incubation: 37°C, 5-10% CO2, 6-8 weeks. 30-50% positive cases. Bone marrow cultureshave a higher yield.

Serological Tests

SAT: Significant titer 160+, Acute 640+, Complement Fixation: IgG detection, ELISA: Distinguishes IgM & IgG. Rapid Tests: Dipstick, Rose Bengal

Antibiotics

Adults: Doxycycline 45 days, Streptomycin 2 weeks, Children: Cotrimoxazole + Rifampicin/Gentamycin.

Vaccination

No human vaccine, Occupational risk: Attenuated live vaccine, Animals: B. abortus strain 19 vaccine.

questions.text: One week after having unprotected sexual intercourse, a 25-year-old male develops urethral discharge as shown in the image below. What is the most likely causative organism for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Neisseria Gonorrhoeae

Clinical Features

Men

Urethritis, purulent urethral discharge, dysuria, epididymitis, prostatitis.

Women

Cervicitis, vaginal discharge, pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), dysuria, and intermenstrual bleeding.

Rarely can cause Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

Pharyngeal Infection

Often asymptomatic, sore throat, pharyngitis.

Rectal Infection

Proctitis, rectal discharge, pain, and tenesmus, may be asymptomatic.

Disseminated Gonococcal Infection (DGI)

Fever, dermatitis, polyarthralgia, septic arthritis.

Neonates

Ophthalmia neonatorum, conjunctivitis, potential for blindness if untreated.

Diagnosis

Gram Stain

Gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes (particularly useful in men).

Culture

Thayer-Martin or other selective media, oxidase-positive, and carbohydrate utilization tests.

NAAT (Nucleic Acid Amplification Test)

Highly sensitive and specific, recommended for urogenital, pharyngeal, and rectal specimens.

Serological Tests

Not commonly used due to lower sensitivity and specificity compared to NAAT and culture.

Treatment- Green STD kit

First-Line Therapy

Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM as a single dose PLUS doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily for 7 days (if chlamydial co-infection is not excluded).

Alternative Therapy

Gentamicin 240 mg IM as a single dose PLUS azithromycin 2 g orally as a single dose (if ceftriaxone is not available).

questions.text: A child presents to the OPD with a swollen, red knee joint that is tender to touch. Two weeks prior, he had an episode of fever with bloody diarrhea. Which of the following could be the possible organism?
questions.explanation:
Shigella

Features of Shigella
  • Pathogenic Species
    • Shigella dysenteriae
    • Shigella flexneri
    • Shigella boydii
    • Shigella sonnei
  • Transmission
    • Primarily via the fecal-oral route.
    • Commonly spread through contaminated food and water or direct person-to-person contact.
  • Infective Dose
    • Very low; as few as 10-100 bacteria can cause infection.
  • Invasion
    • Invades and multiplies within colonic epithelial cells, leading to cell death and inflammation.

Clinical Presentation of Shigella:
  • Diarrhea:
    • Typically acute and often bloody (dysentery).
    • Incubation Period: 1-3 days after exposure.
    • Prodromal Period: 1-2 days after the incubation period.
  • Abdominal Pain:
    • Severe cramping.
  • Fever:
    • Often high-grade.
  • Tenesmus:
    • Painful straining with defecation.
  • Systemic Symptoms:
    • Malaise, headache, and sometimes vomiting.
  • Complications
    • Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS): Particularly associated with Shigella dysenteriae type 1.
    • Reactive Arthritis: More commonly seen after infection with Shigella flexneri.
    • Neurological Complications: Including seizures, especially in young children.

Diagnosis

Clinical Evaluation:

  • Based on symptoms such as bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever, along with a recent history of exposure (e.g., travel to endemic areas).

Laboratory Tests:

  • Stool Culture: Gold standard for diagnosis; Shigella species identified on selective media like MacConkey agar or XLD (xylose lysine deoxycholate) agar.
  • Biochemical Tests: Confirmatory tests include lactose non-fermentation and indole production, among other specific biochemical characteristics.
  • Serotyping: Identification of specific Shigella species and serotypes using agglutination tests with specific antisera.
  • PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction): Rapid detection of Shigella-specific genes and virulence factors.
  • Stool Microscopy: Presence of leukocytes and erythrocytes in stool samples indicative of invasive diarrhea.

Treatment

Fluid Replacement:

  • Oral Rehydration Therapy (ORT): Recommended for mild to moderate dehydration.
  • Intravenous Fluids: Necessary for severe dehydration or if the patient cannot tolerate oral fluids.

Antibiotic Therapy:

  • Recommended for severe cases, young children, the elderly, and immunocompromised patients.
  • First-line Antibiotics: Include fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin), third-generation cephalosporins (e.g., ceftriaxone), or azithromycin based on susceptibility testing.
  • Increasing antibiotic resistance necessitates periodic updates on local resistance patterns.

Symptomatic Treatment:

  • Antipyretics for managing fever.
  • Avoidance of antimotility agents like loperamide, which can worsen the infection.

questions.text: Pneumonia due to a gram-negative pleomorphic bacillus that grows on chocolate agar and is catalase and oxidase-positive is caused by:
Which of the following statements about scrub typhus is incorrect?

options.label: C
options.text: Produces NLF (non-lactose fermenting) colonies on MacConkey agar

questions.correct_answer: C. Produces NLF (non-lactose fermenting) colonies on MacConkey agar
questions.explanation:
Scrub typhus

Causative agent

Orientia tsutsugamushi - It differs from Rickettsia both genetically and by its cell wall composition i.e. it lacks lipopolysaccharide layer.

Vector

  • Chiggers (larvae of trombiculid mite) (Option A ruled out)

Pathophysiology
  • Scrub typhus is so named because it occurs in areas of scrub vegetation i.e. low lying trees and bushes.
  • It is transmitted by the bite of infected trombiculid mites.
  • Among all stages of mite, the larvae (called chiggers) are the only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Mites can maintain the organisms through transovarial transmission.
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi infects mononuclear cells but still produces fever and rash.

Clinical features

  • The classic presentation of scrub typhus consists of triad of an eschar (at the site of bite), regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash sparing palms and soles. (Option B ruled out)
  • Non-specific manifestations may appear early such as fever, headache, myalgia, cough, and gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • Complications such as encephalitis and interstitial pneumonia may occur rarely in the late stage (due to vascular injury).

Investigations

  • The Weil-Felix test shows OX K+ only.

Treatment

  • Doxycycline is the drug choice.
  • Azithromycin is given alternatively and the drug of choice in children and pregnant women.

Investigation

Presence of gram-negative diplococci

Growth of Neisseria meningitidis on chocolate agar or Thayer-Martin agar

Detection of Neisseria meningitidis DNA

Latex Agglutination Test

Positive for Neisseria meningitidis antigens

Blood Tests

Culture

Growth of Neisseria meningitidis

White Blood Cell Count

Elevated leukocytosis with left shift

Neisseria meningitidis treatment

Empirical Antibiotic Therapy
  • Ceftriaxone or Cefotaxime: First-line treatment for suspected bacterial meningitis, including Neisseria meningitidis.
  • Vancomycin: Added to cover potential penicillin-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae until pathogen identification.
  • Ampicillin: Added if Listeria monocytogenes is suspected, particularly in immunocompromised patients and the elderly.

Definitive Therapy
  • Penicillin G: First choice for confirmed Neisseria meningitidis, given intravenously.
  • Alternative Antibiotics: Continue Ceftriaxone or Cefotaxime if pathogen is susceptible.
  • Duration: Typically lasts 7 days.
  • Dexamethasone: May be used to reduce inflammation and neurological complications, especially if started before or with the first antibiotic dose.

Chemoprophylaxis for Close Contacts
  • Rifampin: 600 mg every 12 hours for 2 days (adults); 10 mg/kg every 12 hours for 2 days (children).
  • Ciprofloxacin: Single dose of 500 mg (adults); not typically used in children.
  • Ceftriaxone: Single intramuscular dose of 250 mg (adults) or 125 mg (children).

Vaccination Prophylaxis
  • Meningococcal polysaccharide vaccines (serogroups A, C, Y, W135): 2 doses for children aged 3-18 months or a single dose for older children and adults.
  • Not given to children less than 2-3 years of age.

Indications for Vaccination

  • Splenic dysfunction
  • Terminal complement component deficiency
  • International travelers

questions.text: What is the likely pathogen responsible for an 8-year-old boy's continuous diarrhea, starting 20 hours ago, which is rice watery in consistency, causing drowsiness, unresponsiveness, sunken eyes, and poor skin turgor?

A 34-year-old HIV-positive male presented with low-grade fever, cough, night sweats, and weight loss for the past 3 weeks. In view of TB investigations, the Mantoux test was negative; chest X-ray showed non-specific findings, and an adequate amount of sputum could not be collected for slide examination. Which of the following is used to diagnose latent TB infection in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Investigations

Purpose

Advantages

Limitations

Sputum smear

  • Initial screening for pulmonary TB.
  • Samples are stained using the Ziehl-Neelsen method or Auramine-O stain to visualize acid-fast bacilli (AFB) under a microscope.
  • Quick and inexpensive. Can provide results within a few hours.
  • Low sensitivity, especially in cases of extrapulmonary TB or in patients with HIV.
  • Cannot differentiate between Mycobacterium tuberculosis and non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM).

Culture Methods
  • Confirm the diagnosis of TB and assess drug susceptibility.
  • Solid Media: Sputum is inoculated onto solid culture media like Löwenstein-Jensen or Middlebrook agar.
  • Liquid Media: Automated systems like BACTEC or MGIT are used to detect growth faster.
  • The gold standard for TB diagnosis.
  • Allows for drug susceptibility testing.
  • Time-consuming; results can take weeks.
  • Requires specialized laboratory facilities.

Xpert MTB/RIF
  • Detects Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance.
  • Method:
  • A cartridge-based system that performs nucleic acid amplification (NAAT).
  • Sputum or other specimens are processed directly in the cartridge.
  • Rapid results (within 2 hours).
  • High sensitivity and specificity.
  • Simultaneously detects rifampicin resistance.
  • More expensive than smear microscopy.
  • Does not provide full drug susceptibility testing.

LAMP (Loop-Mediated Isothermal Amplification)
  • Detects DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Method:
  • Amplifies DNA at a constant temperature without the need for thermal cycling.
  • Sputum or other specimens are used.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 hours).
  • High specificity and sensitivity.
  • Can be performed at the point of care.
  • Used for patients with HIV with CD4+ counts of less than 100 cells/μL irrespective of signs and symptoms of TB.
  • Less widely available than PCR-based tests.
  • Cannot detect drug resistance directly.

TrueNat
  • Point-of-care test for TB detection.
  • Method:
  • Uses a micro-PCR technology to amplify DNA.
  • Results are available within 60 minutes.
  • Portable and easy to use in peripheral health facilities.
  • Provides results quickly, facilitating immediate treatment decisions.
  

Line Probe Assay (LPA)
  • Detects TB and drug resistance (rifampicin and isoniazid).
  • Method:
    • Sputum samples are processed, and DNA is extracted.
    • Amplified DNA is hybridized to specific probes on a membrane strip.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 days).
  • Can detect multiple mutations associated with drug resistance.
  • Requires a laboratory setup and trained personnel.
  • Not suitable for all strains of TB.

RFLP
  • IS6110 restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis is widely used for molecular epidemiological studies of tuberculosis.
  • Restriction enzymes Nru I, EcoN I, Pst I, and Pvu II were used to analyze IS6110 fingerprints in Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains H37Rv (virulent) and H37Ra (avirulent).

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with complaints of fever and sore throat. On examination, he has extensive cervical swelling and a well-demarcated white-gray exudative substance adherent to his oropharynx and attempts to remove this membrane result in bleeding. The parents report that all his childhood vaccines were skipped due to religious beliefs. A throat swab under Albert's staining is as below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Diphtheria

Clinical Features

Complications
  • Sore throat
  • Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia)
  • Low-grade fever
  • Grey Pseudomembrane formation in the throat that bleeds on removal
  • Non-healing ulcers covered by grey membrane on the skin
  • Myocarditis
  • Neurological complications (e.g., paralysis, neuropathy)
  • Renal failure
  • Airway obstruction

Culture Media

Colony appearance

Evaluation

Loeffler’s serum slope
  • Small
  • Circular opaque disks
  • Glistening,
  • White with a yellow tinge
  • Advantage: Growth can be detected as early as 6–8 hours.
  • The best medium for metachromatic granule production
  • Disadvantage: Supports the growth of other throat commensals also

Potassium tellurite agar

(McLeod’s and Hoyle’s-modified PTA)
  • Grey or black colour
  • Advantage: Throat commensals are inhibited
  • Disadvantage: Colonies appear only after 48 hours of incubation

Sheep blood agar
  • Small
  • Circular
  • White
  • Sometimes hemolytic(mitis biotype)
  • Differentiate colonies from streptococcal or staphylococcal pharyngitis, which may simulate diphtheria.
  • The serum slope may show growth in 4-8 hours but, if negative, will have to be incubated for 24 hours

Type

Components

Function

Albert Solution 1
  • Malachite Green for organism staining
  • Toluidine Blue for metachromatic staining
  • Enhances contrast and specificity in staining.

Albert Solution 2
  • Iodine
  • Specifically targets volutin or Babes-Ernst granules.

questions.text: What are common causes of granuloma formation?
questions.explanation:
Correct option A

Aspect Description
Definition - A granuloma is a localized, organized collection of immune cells, typically formed in response to persistent, indigestible, or challenging substances that the immune system cannot eliminate.
Types of Granulomas - Infectious Granulomas: Result from chronic infections by certain bacteria (e.g., Mycobacterium tuberculosis), fungi, or parasites. - Non-Infectious Granulomas: Can be caused by non-infectious factors, including foreign bodies, immune disorders, or unknown etiologies (e.g., sarcoidosis).
Cellular Composition - Macrophages: Play a central role in granuloma formation by engulfing and presenting antigens. - T lymphocytes: Participate in the immune response and regulation of granulomatous inflammation. - Giant Cells: Multinucleated cells formed by the fusion of macrophages, often seen in the center of granulomas.
Histological Appearance - Granulomas have a characteristic appearance under a microscope, featuring a central area of altered macrophages surrounded by lymphocytes and fibrosis. - The center may contain caseous necrosis in certain infectious granulomas.
Common Causes - Infectious Causes: Mycobacteria (e.g., Mycobacterium tuberculosis), fungi (e.g., Histoplasma), parasites (e.g., Schistosoma). - Non-Infectious Causes: Foreign bodies (e.g., sutures, talc), immune disorders (e.g., sarcoidosis).
Clinical Significance - Granulomas can be protective, isolating and containing the source of infection or irritation. - In certain cases, granulomas may contribute to tissue damage and dysfunction, especially if they are numerous or affect vital organs.
Diagnostic Methods - Microscopy: Histological examination of tissue samples, such as biopsies, to identify the characteristic cellular arrangement of granulomas. - Imaging: Radiological studies, such as X-rays or CT scans, may reveal the presence of granulomas in affected organs.
Treatment - Treatment depends on the underlying cause. In infectious granulomas, antimicrobial therapy is often necessary. - Non-infectious granulomas may require anti-inflammatory medications or treatment of the underlying condition.
Complications - Granulomas can lead to fibrosis and scarring, affecting the normal structure and function of organs. - Complications may arise if granulomas are numerous, large, or located in critical areas.

questions.text: A firefighter was admitted with fever, cough, culture shown in the image reveals gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacilli. Colonies transilluminating while passing under UV light. Choose the correct agent.
questions.explanation:
Diagnostic Method

Description

Specific Features for Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Sample Collection

Collect specimens such as sputum, urine, wound swabs, blood, ear discharge, eye discharge, or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

Specimens vary based on the site of infection.

Microscopy

Gram stain

Gram-negative rods; motile with flagella.

Culture

Growth on common laboratory media:

Blood agar

Produces beta-hemolytic gray, moist colonies.

MacConkey agar

Produces pale, non-lactose fermenting colonies, Fluorescence under UV light.

Nutrient agar

Produces large, irregular colonies with a metallic sheen.

Peptone water

Forms uniform turbidity with surface pellicle.

Cetrimide Agar

Selective medium that inhibits other Gram-negative bacteria; specifically selected for Pseudomonas aeruginosa; pigment production (e.g., pyocyanin).
 

King’s medium

used to increase pigment production by pseudomonas

Biochemical Tests

Various biochemical tests to identify specific metabolic properties:

Oxidase test

Positive

Catalase test

Positive

ICUT Test:

Indole test

Negative

Citrate test

Positive

Urease test

Negative

Triple sugar test

Shows alkaline slant with no gas and hydrogen sulfide.

Molecular Methods

PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction), 16S rRNA sequencing

Provides specific and sensitive detection of Pseudomonas aeruginosa DNA.

Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing

Disk diffusion method, Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) testing

Determines the susceptibility of Pseudomonas aeruginosa to various antibiotics.

questions.text: A group of students consumed fried rice in a restaurant. Six hours later, they start vomiting. What is the etiological agent?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features

Details


 

Food Poisoning
  • Two distinct forms: diarrhoeal and emetic.
  • Diarrhoeal form: Linked to contaminated meat, poultry, vegetables, and pasta; symptoms appear 8-16 hours post-ingestion.
  • Symptoms: Abdominal pain, diarrhoea (vomiting less common, fever rare)
  • Emetic form: Associated with cooked rice, especially fried rice; nausea and vomiting within 1-6 hours.
  • Some cases may include diarrhoea

Other Infections
  • Opportunistic infections: Ocular infections, meningitis, septicemia, endocarditis, osteomyelitis
  • More common in immunocompromised individuals, intravenous drug users, neonates, and post-surgical patients

Diagnostic Method

Details

Food Poisoning
  • Culture of implicated food essential.
  • >105 B. cereus cells per gram confirms the diagnosis.
  • Quantitative stool cultures with at least 105 cells per gram support diagnosis.

Culture Characteristics
  • Aerobic growth at 37°C on sheep blood agar.
  • β-hemolytic colonies with frosted glass appearance.
  • Motile, lecithinase positive, fermenting salicin

Selective Media
  • MYPA aids in isolating B. cereus from faeces and other sources

Microscopy
  • Spore-forming, Gram-positive bacilli.
  • Motile

questions.text: A farmer presents with fever and subconjunctival hemorrhage. The microscopic agglutination test turns to be positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Causative Agent

Leptospira interrogans (bacteria)

Transmission
  • Zoonotic disease
  • Indirect: Contact with water, moist soil, or surfaces contaminated with animal urine.
  • Direct: Contact with urine or parturition products from infected animals.

Pathogenesis Phases
  • Septicemic Phase: Entry through mucosa or skin, dissemination via bloodstream to organs.
  • Immune Phase: Antibodies develop, spirochetes disappear from blood; antigen-antibody complexes form, and renal colonization occurs.

Clinical Syndromes
  • Mild Anicteric Illness: Seen in 90% of cases, flu-like symptoms with fever, headache, conjunctival suffusion, nausea, vomiting, and myalgia.
  • Weil’s Disease: Severe icteric illness in 10% of cases; rapid progression, fatality rate of 5-15%.

Culture Media
  • Ellinghausen-McCullough-Johnson-Harris (EMJH) medium is commonly used for culturing Leptospira species showing Dinger’s ring.

​​​​​​​

  • It is a semi-solid or liquid medium that supports the slow-growing leptospires, often requiring incubation for weeks.
  • Specimen Sources: Blood, urine, or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) samples are often used, depending on the stage of infection.
  • Other culture media are Korthoff and Fletcher.

Diagnosis

  • Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT): Considered the gold standard for Leptospira detection, MAT measures antibodies in serum samples.
  • The Modified Faine’s Criteria used to aid in the diagnosis of leptospirosis, especially in endemic areas.This scoring system combines clinical, epidemiological and laboratory data to increase diagnostic accuracy.
  • PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction): Provides a faster diagnosis by detecting leptospira DNA in blood or urine, especially effective in the early stage.
  • ELISA: Used for antibody detection and is helpful for confirming infection in the later stages.

Treatment

Antibiotics: Early antibiotic therapy is crucial and often involves:

  • Doxycycline: Typically used for mild cases and prophylaxis.
  • Penicillin or Ampicillin: Preferred for severe cases.

questions.text: A person with the H/o long-term sexual relationship presented with painful ulcers on his genitals with tender lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis?
A patient admitted with fever and nuchal rigidity. CSF analysis shows decreased glucose and increased protein and neutrophils. Choose the correct treatment
questions.explanation:
Bacterial Meningitis in Adults and Prevention

Causes

Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitides are the primary causes. Listeria monocytogenes is a significant risk in adults over 50, especially in those with diabetes, alcoholism, or weakened immune systems.

Pathophysiological Process

Classic Triad of Symptoms
  • Fever
  • Headache
  • Nuchal rigidity (stiff neck)

CSF Findings
  • Opening pressure: Elevated
  • Predominant cell type: Polymorphonuclear neutrophils (PMNs)
  • Protein: Elevated
  • Glucose: Decreased
  • Gross appearance: Turbid

Treatment
  • Immediate Management:
    • Start with intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover pathogens.
    • First-line antibiotic of choice: Ceftriaxone
    • Treatment is then adjusted based on the identified organism and its susceptibility
  • Adjunctive Therapy: Dexamethasone may be given to reduce inflammation and prevent complications, particularly if administered early.
  • Supportive Care: Manage complications like raised intracranial pressure and seizures.

Prevention
  • Vaccines for H. influenzae type b, N. meningitidis, and S. pneumoniae. No vaccine currently exists for group B meningococcal infections.
  • Chemoprophylaxis: Close contacts of individuals with meningococcal meningitis should receive prophylactic antibiotics like rifampicin, ciprofloxacin, azithromycin or ceftriaxone to reduce the risk of secondary infections.
    • Rifampicin - 600 mg 12 hourly for 2 days
    • Ciprofloxacin - 500 mg single dose
    • Azithromycin 500 mg single dose
    • Ceftriaxone - 250 mg Intramuscular single dose

questions.text: KAT G mutation associated with:

KatG gene mutation

INH is a prodrug, converted to the active form by catalase-peroxidase produced by the Kat G gene. The mutated catalase enzyme does not form the active drug

KasA gene mutation

Component of cell wall mycolic acid

InhA gene overexpression

Causes cross-resistance to Ethionamide (second-line drug)

Acid-fast bacilli (AFB) smear, GeneXpert MTB/RIF, Culture and sensitivity testing

Gram stain, Blood culture, Urine antigen test

Nontreponemal tests (e.g., Venereal Disease Research Laboratory [VDRL] test, Rapid Plasma Reagin [RPR] test), Treponemal tests (e.g., Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption [FTA-ABS] test)

Microscopic examination of clinical samples, Culture on selective media, DNA probe or PCR-based tests
